glossary.title: An Informal Glossary of Terms
glossary.headnote: Many of the words in this glossary are not formally defined in the book either because they are viewed as prerequisites to a course in discrete mathematics or are terms in computer science that some students may be unfamiliar with.

gi.title: An
gi.p: When referring to “an entity” we mean that the object can be any of the elements is some set. For example, if you say that n is an integer, it could be any integer.

gi.title: Bit
gi.p: The smallest unit of computer memory, normally represented as a 0 or 1.

gi.title: Byte
gi.p: A basic unit of computer memory containing eight s, normally modeled as a sequence of eight 0’s and 1’s.

gi.title: Complex Number
gi.p: A number of the form a + b \boldsymbol{i}, where a and b are real numbers and \boldsymbol{i}^2=-1.

gi.title: Composite Integer
gi.p: A positive integer is composite if it is greater than one and is the product of two positive integers greater than one. For example, 10 (equal to 2\cdot 5) is composite. Any positive integer greater than one that is not composite is .

gi.title: Constant
gi.p: A numerical value that is unchanging . The value might be unknown and it still may be represented with a symbol. For example if we are discussing the process of sorting a file of N numbers, N is considered a constant with respect to the sorting algorithm. Constants can become variables though. If we have designed a sorting algorithm, and want to analyze its efficiency, we would consider N to be a variable.

gi.title: Creative Commons
gi.p: An organization which has created several open licenses for creative works such as Applied Discrete Structures.

gi.title: Data Structure
gi.p: A format for organizing, processing, retrieving and storing data.

gi.title: Distinct
gi.p: Two entities are distinct if they are not the same. For example, any two student ID numbers at a school should be distinct. If not, confusion could ensue. See also .

gi.title: Even Integer
gi.p: Any that is equal to two times an integer. That includes 0, since 0 = 2 \cdot 0.

gi.title: Factor
gi.p: If an algebraic expression is the product of several expressions, each of those expressions is a factor.

gi.title: Iff
gi.p: Shorthand for “if and only if”

gi.title: Integer
gi.p: Whole number, whether positive, negative or zero.

gi.title: Irrational Number
gi.p: A number that is not equal to any fraction. \sqrt{2} is one we prove to be irrational in the book.

gi.title: LaTeX
gi.p: A markup language used for books and papers with lots of mathematics, which is built on . uses as an intermediate format to produce PDF and print output.

gi.title: Multiples
gi.p: Multiples of a number c are \dots, -3c,—2c,-c,0,c,2c,3c,\dots

gi.title: Natural Numbers
gi.p: In this book, its the numbers 0,1,2,3,4,… . There isn’t 100% agreement here. Some people say its the numbers 1,2,3,4, … . We call those numbers the positive integers. The symbol we use of the natural numbers is \mathbb{N}. There is no consistent definition of positive complex numbers.

gi.title: Nonnegative Number
gi.p: A number that is either positive or zero.

gi.title: Odd Integer
gi.p: An integer n is odd if there exists an integer k so that n = 2k + 1. Any integer that is not even is odd.

gi.title: Positive Number
gi.p: A positive number is a number that is greater than zero. Normally visualized as being to the right of zero on a conventional number line. The set of positive integers is denoted \mathbb{P}. The sets of positive rational and real numbers are denoted \mathbb{Q}^+ and \mathbb{R}?^+, respectively

gi.title: Powers
gi.p: Powers of a nonzero number c are \dots, c^{-3},c^{-2},c^{-1},1,c^1,c^2,c^3,\dots. Recall that c^0=1.

gi.title: PreTeXt
gi.p: An authoring and publishing system for authors of textbooks, research articles, and monographs, especially in STEM disciplines. Applied Discrete Structures is produced using PreTeXt.

gi.title: Prime
gi.p: A positive integer that is divisible by exactly two positive integers, itself and 1. One is not prime, but 2 is the oddest prime because it’s even. See also .

gi.title: Queue
gi.p: A conventional waiting line, with the first come-first serve service rule. A queue is a common in computer science. See also .

gi.title: Rational Number
gi.p: Any real number that is equal to a quotient two integers, a/b, with b \neq 0.

gi.title: Real Number
gi.p: For the purposes of this book, think of the numbers on a standard number line. All of the points make up the set of real numbers.

gi.title: SageMath
gi.p: An open source computer algebra system for a wide range of symbolic and numerical mathematical computations. Originally named simply Sage.

gi.title: Stack
gi.p: A similar to a queue, but where the last come-first serve service rule is used. This wouldn’t be a fair waiting line rule, but it is a very useful data structure. See also

gi.title: Subtraction
gi.p: Subtraction is really addition of the negation of a number: a-b=a+(-b).

gi.title: Term
gi.p: If an algebraic expression is the sum of several expressions, each of those expressions is a term. For example there are three terms in the expression 2y + x-(w+1)/2. Note that subtraction is considered the same as addition here.

gi.title: Unique
gi.p: We say a mathematical entity is unique when there’s nothing else like it. For example, the solution, x=3 to the equation 2x+1=7 is unique. No other number solves the equation. See also .

gi.title: Variable
gi.p: A quantity whose value that can vary within a specified set. Normally represented by an algebraic symbol. For discrete variables it is customary to use the letters in the range from i to n, but this isn’t a rigid rule. Letters at the end of the alphabet are traditionally used for continuous variables.
